i would personally either just have a single root partition scheme or use LVM - creating pre-sized partitions for your mount points can be really annoying further down the line
its logical volume manager.  It allows you to divide a disk up into partitions virtually so that the partitions can be resized on demand
http://tldp.org/HOWTO/LVM-HOWTO/benefitsoflvmsmall.html
LVM is difficult to implement, but if you really want to seperate your mount points it is the best way
i would personally just have a default ubuntu install with a single / and the file system as simple directories though
not very easily, the LVM system has to all be mounted together
its certainly not good for sharing partitions between distros
in fact most distros wont be able to read the LVM drives at all unless they have the driver module loaded
yes, thats what its there for - its ideal if you know you will be buying more hard disks in the future
for example i have a 250gb disk now.  If I bought two more 250gb disks and added them to LVM, it would see one single 750gb disk - I could partition it into chunks as I wanted
the only downside is that it is more complicated than a standard filesystem, theres a bit of a learning curve
redhat and Fedora Core come with LVM set up as standard, ubuntu can be installed with it using the "alternative install disk"
no ext3 is formatted on top of the LVM logical drives
